data.title: Samuel J. Keith, Ph.D.

data.text:
Courses Taught:

University of Georgia (2018-present):

PRTM 4700 | Social Science Methods in Natural Resources (syllabus)

Role: Teaching Assistant

Semesters Taught: Fall 2019, Fall 2020

Frequency of Meetings: 50 mins., 3 times/week

Enrollment/Student Profile: 20-30 students, undergraduate

Course description: Designed to introduce students to basic skills and methods essential in planning, designing and evaluating social science studies related to natural resource management and outdoor recreation.

PRTM 1100E | Introduction to Travel and Tourism (syllabus)

Role: Teaching Assistant

Semesters Taught: Summer 2019, Summer 2020, Fall 2020

Frequency of Meetings: ONLINE, self-paced

Enrollment/Student Profile: 20-30 students, undergraduate

Course Description: Overview of travel tourism in a global context. Students become acquainted with the economic, socio-cultural, demographic, and environmental impacts that tourism has on the world community.

PRTM 4650/6650 | Parks, Environmental Education, and Tourism Management Field Study (syllabus)

Role: Teaching Assistant

Semesters Taught: Summer 2019

Frequency of Meetings: Field Studies course that lasted 4 weeks

Enrollment/Student Profile: 11-20 students, undergraduate

Course Description: Students explore the fields and professions of environmental education, protected areas management, and tourism management around the state of Georgia. Course content covers program evaluation, content knowledge, personnel and visitor management, and natural resource management.

PRTM 5410/7410 | Protected Area Management (syllabus) Role: Teaching Assistant

Semesters Taught: Spring 2019, Spring 2020

Frequency of Meetings: 2.75 hrs., once/week

Enrollment/Student Profile: 20-30 students, undergraduate & graduate

Course Description: Overview of stewardship and management issues facing protected natural resources areas both in North America and around the world.

PRTM 5700/7700 | Community Tourism: Impacts, Planning and Management (syllabus) Role: Teaching Assistant

Semesters Taught: Spring 2019

Frequency of Meetings: 75 mins., 2 times/week

Enrollment/Student Profile: 20-30 students, undergraduate & graduate

Course Description: Examines social-cultural aspects surrounding the impacts, planning, and management of tourism development at the community level. A survey of various topics prepare students to undertake a community-focused research project examining residents’ perceptions of tourism impacts as an aspect of tourism planning to inform management decisions.

Clemson University (2014-2016):

LS 1450 | Camping & Backpacking (syllabus) Role: Instructor

Semesters Taught: Fall 2014, Spring 2015, Fall 2015, Spring 2016 (2 sections per semester)

Frequency of Meetings: 2.5 hrs., once/week

Enrollment/Student Profile: 10-15 students, undergraduate & graduate

Course Description: Basic camping and backpacking skills including map and compass reading, outdoor cooking, hazards and safety, gear selection, site selection, Leave No Trace, and trip planning. Students demonstrated learned skills on a two-night backpacking trip.

LS 1650 | Inland Kayak Touring (syllabus) Role: Instructor

Semesters Taught: Fall 2014, Spring 2015, Fall 2015, Spring 2016

Frequency of Meetings: 2.5 hrs., once/week

Enrollment/Student Profile: 10-15 students, undergraduate & graduate

Course Description: Introduction to basic skills necessary for safe enjoyment of flatwater (non-tidal waters: lakes, slow moving rivers) kayak touring. Students learned equipment selection, strokes, safety, and rescue techniques. Students demonstrated learned skills on a one-day kayaking trip.

Invited Lectures:

PRTM 4700 – Social Science Methods in Natural Resources

– Ethics and Research. (2019, Sept. 25)

– Making Quality Presentations of Your Results. (2018, Nov. 14)
